Hello yes, I can explain what's going on. So basically, it's known as the "gifted child" complex. It's a child that has always seemed too just.. 'get' the read on others. Always hypervigilant, mind turned on 24/7. This child can recognize, predict, and anticipate the stressors, moods, preferences and emotional injury in other people to the point it's scary to others around them.

In other words, they are extremely analytical to the point that, analysis paralysis is a daily occurrence for them. For any dilemma in life, it requires steps to reach a conclusion. Say we have a dilemma; it takes 100 steps to get there mentally, to its goal. Normal people take it step 1. Then step 2. Then step 3. etc.

The 'gifted' child is already at step 80 - 90 within seconds, and by the hour is up, he's at 100. Other people can waste an entire day or week on it, to figure out the solution to their own personal problem. The 'gifted' child will try to provide them the answer.

But the other person can't see it. They aren't past step 5 yet let alone step 100. And so they just. refuse. to listen. Much to the frustration, and alienation of the 'gifted' child.

This child is always usually from a dysfunctional family (arguing, verbal abuse, emotional abuse). This child is usually the youngest, and this child learned ALL of this because:

He had to in order to be able to prevent his or her parents from blowing up. He had to parent his own family in a way.

And when their family DID blow up, he would isolate. Using his own imagination/thoughts as a fantasy land to escape to, to process and ruminate. Usually in bed often.

That's what's shaped who we are, imo.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27734545
You are right to be unsettled, but you also need to remember to put yourself in their shoes and have empathy. They were probably utterly heartbroken by the prospect of never having their own children. They could have wallowed in it for a lifetime, but instead they sublimated that heart break into love for you and gave you an immensely better life.
But it is more than that, anon. Just as you are processing being lied to for years, they are processing having lived that lie and handling the consequences of it. Now, this doesn't justify keeping it secret; I want you to take it, instead, as an explanation for their reactions (shutting down and anger) to prodding. They are going through a lot too and are having issues communicating it.
Everything that you wrote you were feeling is understandable, totally valid, and honestly pretty restrained. You need to be patient with them but, more than that, you need to be patient with yourself. Give yourself time to process this before you start digging up more secrets. Limit your expectations for what sort of closure you will find.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27733883
Time for a serious answer.

If you're really passionate about fitness, and are okay with just making decent(ish) money, personal training can be a good route to take.

The problem with being a Personal Trainer is that the money is either fairly good or surprisingly bad (with little in-between) and finding and maintaining a client base means that achieving a stable income can be tricky.

Many gyms' personal trainers are responsible for building and maintaining their own client base (mostly from free trials offered to regular gym members). They don't just hire you at a set salary and *give* you clients to work with. You need to cultivate your client base yourself - so there's a fair amount of cold calling and sales work involved. Not always, and not a ton, but it's apart of the job.

Once you do build a solid client base you just need to pray that you don't have multiple clients quit at the same time, or you'll be stuck with a gap in both work and income.

$1000 isn't bad for a certification but it isn't worth all that much. Better than nothing, but you'll be competing with peers that have degrees (often advanced degrees) in physiology, kinesiology, nutrition, and sports medicine. And people with those qualifications will always be more attractive to employers and clients than you own excellent physique.

TL;DR:
>The pay and workload is inconsistent but can be pretty decent
>There is more hustle/sales/client cultivation involved than you probably expect
>You'd be decently qualified between your personal experience and that certification, but will be notable less qualified than some of your competition who have advanced degrees - even if most of them have worse physiques than yours
>It's a decent option if you're really passionate about it. But it isn't the best choice if having something stable and lucrative is an absolute must for you.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>27729897
I have C-PTSD, I can tell you a little about what it's like for me. From your post you basically described what it feels like for me - mine was a result of prolonged abuse from peers and I have very low self-esteem, I believe myself to be everything they told me I am although the reality (as demonstrated by my actions/how I live my life) is the complete opposite. I have a completely skewed sense of... stress? danger? idk. but I will have a complete and utter mental breakdown over my car not properly starting yet face potentially life-ruining things (ie failing university) with "oh, okay. whatever". I am pretty sure ongoing depression is an essential component of PTSD, at least it is for me. I do not trust anyone, ever. >>27731987 is right, it's schizo-adjacent. I 'logically' believe and know that there is no existing network of people who all share secrets about me and know everything about me and what I've done before they meet me, and who are 'out to get me', but my gut tells me otherwise. I feel like everybody in their cars stare at me, and I get intensely paranoid if a car is following me for too long - I drive around in circles to shake them what feels like every other night. I never experienced any type of schizo thoughts prior to my experience. In terms of flashbacks, I do often dissociate and think about it, but I also likely have ADHD so I feel like that's been a thing for me for a long time - don't take my word on this symptom. However, I do have dreams about it constantly that wake me up during the night. It used to be multiple times a night, now it's more like one occurrence a couple of times a week.

OP, when has TV ever represented mental illness of ANY kind in a realistic way? Come on now, don't be a fucking retard.

A friend of mine is going through PTSD after being raped. She's been really depressed for a long time. She has regular bouts of anxiety. She has severe anxiety attacks. She struggled to face what happened to her, and suddenly couldn't stand being alone. She was already a very sociable person, but she went through a bad phase of going out on a bender every single weekend, and hanging out with friends every single night until late because she couldn't stand to be alone with her thoughts. Any time I see her on her own, she's doing one of her nervous 'anxiety tics'. She literally can't be alone with her own thoughts before she feels like shit again. She's expressed suicidality many times.
Thankfully, her new psychiatrist recognised her issues for PTSD and not just 'depression', so she's finally been able to work through it in a healthy way (they require different approaches).

I was raped, myself. And now that I think about it, I had similar behavioural patterns for a few months afterwards. I would immerse myself in videogames or I'd lay in bed listening to music literally all fucking day, just so I could avoid thinking about anything - not just the subject of the rape. I cried literally every day. All day. Even at work. I often skipped work because I needed a mindless videogame break from the world. I was always anxious. I hit myself a lot. If I was left with my own thoughts for too long, I would get suicidal. I had horrible intrusive thoughts about the event, and they made me feel physically sick. I think I probably had PTSD, too.

I dunno what you went through, but I'm sorry.
You have the support I never had. Please trust your psychiatrist and work with them on this. Let them help you. I've seen my friend get so much healthier over the last few weeks. You can have that, too.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>27729897
fellow cPTSD here. I posted the experience in a diff thread once.
>Constant feeling that the air around you feels like a cage
>You feel there is a veil or barrier that separates ‘you’ from ‘life’. Feeling detached from everyone and everything around you
>You always feel, or felt, that you are piloting your body from the inside. Like it’s dead weight, a robot
>Life has always felt like it’s a melancholic movie rolling by, and you are stuck viewing it from a picture screen in your mind
>You struggle to feel positive emotion, only negative
>This is because you genuinely distrust or don’t believe in positive emotions. They don’t sink in, because the feeling of intense shame drowns it out
>You feel like a phoney, a stranger to yourself because you have to pretend to be happy
>Life is threatening/alienating. Constantly.
>In videogames when there is a nearby enemy, like skyrim or zelda, battle music plays. Life is like that, 24/7. Except there are no enemies nearby.
>Nowhere feels like home. Not your own home, not other homes, not even your own body
>Feeling like there is an invisible clock constantly ticking, counting down to an ambiguous doomsday. Always feeling like you are running out of time. Even when trying to relax.
>Fears of social interaction. Like somehow, sometime, at any time, you will suffer an unknown humiliation, rejection, confrontation
>No matter who you are with; family, friend, lover. They all have a subtle aura of ‘stranger’ about them
>Cannot feel emotion in the present, you only get to mentally appreciate and somewhat feel it long after the moment is gone
>That very same barrier separating you from everything, cuts between your heart and your mind
>It feel like it’s raining in your head, always
>It’s like if life were a radio station, every one is tuned in. Except you. You’re a few notches out of frequency. You recognise it, you can follow it along. But there’s a constant grainy, hissing whitenoise to life.

I'm gonna tell you why I browse it here.
I'm not sure if I have some very mild autism, but I have plenty of friends IRL, a steady job, a loving wife, planning kids soon, etc. So I pass as a very normal, well-adjusted guy, even if browsing 4chin would tell otherwise.

I'm currently without any good hobbies in my spare time that I can do during the times I browse it here. I do have weekend hobbies (and also spend quite a lot of time with wife during weekends), that's why I rarely post during non-week days.

I'm passionate about certain beliefs I hold, and I like to discuss them. I like to advise Anons in seek of help about my experiences, the reasons why I have those beliefs, and why I think they should do XYZ rather than ABC.

Sometimes I like to just shitpost for the sake of it. I can express my ideas freely, often unpolitely, and even if people will attack my character rather than my ideas - just how it often happens in real life - this cannot harm me. It's just pixels on a screen. It's not like I can suffer character assassination and be "socially cancelled" by speaking the wrong words.

So, what makes 4chan a great place is really freedom of speech. It's the fact that the worst it can happen if I speak my mind is that some rare breed Anon will challenge my ideas with actual arguments, and make me change my mind. And that's not bad at all, even if it can feel mildly confusing when the idea gets throughoutly scrutinized. And if it doesn't and I'm labeled a [insert insult here, often "incel"], I'll still have my job, my wife, my friends, my acquintances, and no one who matters to me is going to be conscious about being close to me because this could negatively impact their reputation due to cancel culture.

I can only guess your boyfriend feels the same.

These jobs are usually remote so location doesn't matter. But the big tech companies (Facebook, Google etc) don't hire directly for entry level roles, they have contracts with staffing agencies to find replaceable click monkeys. I got a job like this at Google but the staffing agency was based in India. seemed like a scam at first actually but it turned out fine and paid well for my first job.

Connection comes from vulnerability.
You don't have to blast people with your insecurities or anything, but you should be able to poke fun of yourself sometimes for little insecurities, and you should talk about your personal opinions and thoughts - even when they're unpopular. Tell people when you've had a hard day, or you're feeling down. Laugh at yourself when you're feeling embarrassed. Get good at asking for help.

Some faggot is bound to say "noooo never show your feelings. people will hurrrt youuuuu."
Those people are the loneliest faggots in the world. Do not trust them.

I've dealt with social anxiety all my fucking life. I got really good at small talk and general chat with other people, but the thing I've always struggled with is sharing my insecurities. I always put on a strong facade, and joke away my troubles. So of course, I always struggled to make long-term, deep connections with people.
I'm only recently getting better at it. And now I have a good group of friends who I really love.

Don't go full trauma-dump on people lol. But share a little crumb of 'the innermost you' once in a while. You can show your power level later.

>>27729381
I'm not a man, but one major difference I noticed between my parents' relationship (unhealthy) and my sister's relationship (healthy) was the difference in how they handled conflict, and how often they simply... played together.

Handling conflict in a healthy way, giving constructive criticism, being supportive, and taking constructive criticism on board, are all SUPER important skills to have in any relationship. They're crucial to long-term relationship health.

I'd argue that playing together is almost as important.

When my parents were in the mood to play with one another (teasing, joking, singing, watching funny TV shows together, etc...), they were at their best. And their relationship seemed stronger in the hours or days following. But they rarely played together, and over the years, they stopped enjoying one another's company. Eventually, they fell into the habit of NEVER being in the same room together, except to eat or sleep.

My sister and her partner play a lot. They roast the shit out of each other, they make silly in-jokes, they drink together and laugh together. They tease each other and purposefully annoy each other for fun. It's really lovely to see. My sister makes a point of trying to cheer up her partner when he's in a shitty mood by playing with him. My mum never did that for my dad.

Idk I didn't mean to go on a rant about playing, but it's really important.
Even my own last relationship was ultimately super fucking unhealthy, but I loved him to bits because we played so well together. You'd be surprised how strong that glue is.

I dress in plain t-shirts/shirts/trousers, and starve myself so my body stays childlike, which is childish in itself but other than that, I don't really understand. (woman, grew up exposed to so much fetish stuff the idea of having boobs just feels gross to me now).

Those are all of the traits that could be childish I can think of, but other than that, I'm a levelheaded, polite, calm person who never shouts, screams, or asks for anything. Part of me does want to try and become 'normal' but every time I start feeling that way I'm knocked down again by my family saying I'm like a kid and looking down on me for it. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27730385
>I try to split playing games up between college work, art and cleaning the house, but I haven’t got much to do otherwise and there’s little in my area for social options otherwise.
Are you taking classes in a nearby community college? If so, once you move on from HS and continue finishing your associate's degree, try to find some club within the community college that aligns to your interests - especially the major you might want to do, as you can always have fun with people interested on the same field as you do. I say this since, if you finish the AA, your time to socialize in 4-year unis to complete the other 2 years of your degree will be extremely difficult, as the degree of work on the latter two years is way greater than the former two in your community college.
And I'm not saying this to berate the quality of community college education - I graduated from one in 1.5 years and immediately transferred without problem - but because your degree emphasis is really something else in comparison to gen eds + lower division courses of your major in CC.
Really, I strongly recommend the clubs within your community college as you will NOT get such a thing once you transfer to a 4-year. If you are extremely education-focused, you are supposed to network with your professors who will give you recommendation letters to graduate school; you will, sadly, not be able to socialize much with your peers, as they do the same hard work on their BA thesis as much as you do.
>I’ll see if there’s space in the garage, thank you.
Make sure to keep one, for the sake of nostalgia. There is no need to keep your room extremely dry and without decoration - this will not make you look less "childish." Just know the degree of which you want to decorate your room so you don't become one of those hoarders with a fuck ton of useless shit like thousands of Hallmark cards or minions stuff.
>I can’t bring myself to care.
cont.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27730067
Maybe counterproductive, but think of yourself as your own child. Or a sim, or something. Just think of yourself, particularly your physical form, as that of an individual you are responsible for. If you had a human life you were responsible for, you'd want them to eat healthy food, sleep regular hours, succeed in their job/study, be able to comfortably interact with others, and have at least one or two friends they can count on in times of sadness.

You sound like a nice person to be around from your description of yourself, but unfortunately, the world has all these notions of a "good" life that it expects you to adhere to as strictly as possible. So even if you're perfectly happy to live a certain way, if it isn't in accordance with what you're "meant" to do you'll receive at least some judgment.

Try to fill up your time with things that are productive and worthwhile. Try and build skills in fields relevant to your future degree/career, or skills in a field that makes you happy. Try and take care of yourself, eat food you enjoy, wear clothes you feel comfortable in, drink a lot of water, try and get on a healthy sleep schedule. Don't starve yourself, if you really don't want to gain weight or develop there are ways to eat healthier foods in small doses, but starving yourself will only make you physically and mentally weak. I know things are rough, and I can't say with absolute certainty that things will get significantly better soon, or for a long time, but I think it's more worthwhile to try and live a life that makes you happy and fulfilled than to give up at age 18.
